data.event: 1949: Gustav Wagner establishes the first professional organization for informatics in Germany. It is currently known as the Deutsche Gesellschaft fur Medizinische Dokumentation, Informatik und Statistik, which in English means: the German Society for Medical Computer Science and Statistics Documentation.

1959: A seminal article in the area of informatics is published by Ledley and Lusted in Science, titled "Reasoning Foundations of Medical Diagnosis," which discusses the potential role of computers in medical diagnostic processes.

Ledley, R. S., & Lusted, L. B. (1959). Reasoning foundations of medical diagnosis. Science, 130, 3366, 9-21. Retrieved November 2010 from http://www.jstor.org/stable/1758070

1977: The Symposium on Computer Applications in Medical Care (SCAMC) begins, which later becomes the AMIA Annual Symposium. This multidisciplinary meeting has been a driving force in development of the field of medical informatics. (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12087115)
Mid 1980's: During the 1980's, Medical Informatics emerges as a consistent name for the field, a name derived from the French term "Informatique Medicale."

1985: The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) implements computerized information systems, including the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP) information system and the Veterans Health Information Systems and Technology Architecture (VistA).
1989: AMIA, the American Medical Informatics Association, is founded. The organization continues to serve as an important professional association for biomedical health informaticists.

1996: Concerns about privacy increase due to the growth and storage of electronic health information. In response, Congress passes the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), a law that prevents health information from being shared without a patient's consent. Learn more about HIPAA.
1997: The U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs (VA) develops and launches a comprehensive electronic health record: Computerized Patient Record System (CPRS).

2004: The position of National Coordinator for the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) is created, through an Executive Order. Later, it is legislatively mandated in the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH Act) of 2009.

2004: The steering committee for the Minnesota e-Health Initiative is convened. Stakeholders have committed to address complex issues that will result in the improvement of the health of all Minnesotans while reducing healthcare costs.

2007 and 2008: The State of Minnesota passes into law a mandate that, by 2015, all healthcare providers and hospitals must implement an interoperable electronic health record (EHR) system. Learn more about the mandate and implementation plan. Uniform health data standards must be established by 2009. All healthcare providers and payers must implement an e-prescribing system by January 1, 2011.

2008: Minnesota passes groundbreaking health reform legislation to develop 'health care homes,' an approach which offers payment to primary care providers to partner with patients and families to provide coordination of care. The vision of health care homes is to improve health outcomes and quality of life for individuals with chronic health conditions and disabilities.

2009: The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) is signed into law by President Barack Obama. ARRA provides many stimulus opportunities to assist healthcare providers and organizations to adopt electronic health records. The HITECH (Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act) section of the law provides details about health information communication and technology. Learn more about ARRA. Note: Minnesota enacted a law prior to the federal law.

2015: The State of Minnesota mandates that, by this date, all healthcare providers and hospitals must implement an interoperable electronic health record (EHR) system. Learn more about the mandate and implementation plan.
